Introduction

A rectovaginal fistula (RVF) is an aberrant connection between the rectum and the vagina, allowing fecal matter to pass into the vagina.

Pathophysiology



An RVF (

figure 1
) develops within the rectovaginal septum, creating a pathologic connection between the rectum and the vagina that results in the direct passage of fecal matter into the vagina.  RVFs are classified relative to the anal dentate line:



  • Low (anovaginal):  fistulas that occur below the dentate line and are more likely to be associated with occult anal sphincter injuries
  • High (rectovaginal):  fistulas that occur cephalad to the dentate line


Fistulization occurs with prolonged pressure, inflammation, infection, direct (surgical) injury, or malignancies.  Therefore, the most common risk factors include:



  • Obstetric injury:  prolonged and obstructed labor leading to ischemic necrosis of the rectovaginal septum, third- and fourth-degree perineal lacerations (ie, obstetric anal sphincter injuries [OASIS] increase the risk for low RVFs), forceps-assisted vaginal deliveries, and episiotomies
  • Radiation therapy or surgical injury:  direct insult or compromised vascular supply causing tissue breakdown and fistula formation
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (eg, Crohn disease):  chronic inflammation that predisposes to tissue breakdown
  • Trauma:  prolonged pessary use (for pelvic organ prolapse) or posterior vaginal wall mesh repair (for rectoceles), which can cause tissue erosion and fistulization
  • Infection:  perirectal and perianal abscess extension that can result in RVF formation
  • Malignancy:  cervical, vaginal, and rectal cancer that can lead to tissue necrosis and subsequent RVF formation

Pathology



On a microscopic level, the fistulous tract is typically lined by epithelialized tissue.  Chronic inflammation is often present with fibrosis and possible secondary infections.

Clinical presentation



Patients develop symptoms with variable time frames:



  • Immediately following intraoperative injury (eg, rectocele repair, complicated hysterectomies)
  • Weeks to months following childbirth and OASIS perineal lacerations
  • Years after pelvic radiotherapy as a delayed presentation of radiation-induced microvascular injury (ie, endarteritis) and progressive tissue ischemia and breakdown


The classic presentation is uncontrolled passage of gas or feces from the vagina, which is most pronounced in patients with chronic loose stools.  Other symptoms may include malodorous vaginal discharge, recurrent vaginal infections (due to contamination by fecal matter), dyspareunia, and bleeding.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis is clinical and made through discovery of a fistulous tract on vaginal examination.  Methylene blue dye instilled in the rectum may facilitate discovery of small or pinpoint fistulas.  Rectal mucosa seen through larger fistulas may appear as a dark red, velvety lesion.



The diagnostic work-up involves identifying the underlying etiology that resulted in RVF development.  This involves a thorough history and review of systems to guide additional laboratory and imaging evaluations.

Laboratory evaluation



There is no standard diagnostic laboratory evaluation; however, certain studies help diagnose suspected underlying etiologies (eg, C-reactive protein for inflammatory bowel disease).

Imaging



No standard imaging is used for diagnosis, but useful adjuncts in the evaluation of patients with RVF include:



  • Endoanal ultrasonography:  evaluates the integrity of the anal sphincter in patients with prior obstetric trauma and low RVFs
  • Anoscopy/sigmoidoscopy:  evaluates rectal disease (malignancy) and can assist in locating the internal RVF opening
  • CT scan with rectal contrast/MRI:  used in complex cases because it provides detailed images of surrounding pelvic anatomy, the fistula, and possible concurrent perianal abscesses
  • Fistulography:  less commonly used but involves the injection of contrast into the fistula to outline its course on plain films

Differential diagnosis



  • Anorectal fistula (fisutla-in-ano) is a fistula between the anal canal and the perianal or perineal skin; it most commonly develops due to rupture of a perianal abscess with formation of a residual sinus tract.  Examination often shows an external terminus and an indurated tract leading to the rectum.  There is no fecal contamination of the vagina on examination.
  • Colovaginal fistula involves a direct communication between the colon (rather than the rectum) and vagina.  This is most common in patients with a prior hysterectomy (uterus is protective against vaginal fistula formation) and inflammatory bowel diseases (eg, diverticulitis, Crohn disease).
  • Anal incontinence occurs with continuous leakage of fecal matter that may be due to anal incontinence from a deficient anal sphincter (particularly with chronic loose stools) rather than from an aberrant communicating pathway.  On examination, there is no fecal contamination of the vagina.
  • Vaginal abscess can present with malodorous vaginal discharge and dyspareunia; however, this type of abscess lacks a direct communication between the rectum and the vagina.

Management



Conservative management with sitz baths, wound care, and stool-bulking fiber for 3-6 months may be considered, particularly for patients with small fistulas, minimal symptoms, and prior obstetric trauma.  If a nonsurgical approach fails, management typically involves surgical management with a primary fistula repair.

Prognosis



The prognosis for RVF is dependent on the success of the primary surgical repair.  Although success rates are usually high, those rates vary depending on the underlying cause and complexity of the fistula.  Fistulas related to inflammatory bowel disease have high rates of recurrence and may lead to chronic infections, which significantly decrease quality of life.

Summary
